title.narrative: CHAI - Increasing Skilled Birth Attendants inRural Zambia
CHAI- Increasing Skilled Birth Attendants in Rural Zambia

description.narrative: Project to increase the number and quality of health peronnel in rural areas of Zambia, with the overall goal of contributing to reduction of morbidity and mortality in women and their newborn babies. The project also aims to strengthen GRZ systems for training supportive supervision and mentorship and collect evidenced on retention strategies for health personnel in rural settings

Projektets syfte är att öka antalet sjukvårdare, och kvalitén av sjukvården, på zambiska landsbygden. Målet är att bidra till att minska ohälsa och dödsfall bland kvinnor och nyfödda. Projektet hoppas även bidra till att på olika sätt stärka GRZ system för att förbättra tillgång till, och kvalitén av, sjukvården på landsbygden (bl.a. genom utbildning av personal, insamling av data och mentorskapsprogram).

The overall outcome of this intervention was to increase the number of quality Skilled Birth Attendants (SBA's) deployed and accessible in rural districts of Zambia,following a serious human resources for health crisis in preceding years. The SBAs health service provision is expected to increase use of preventive and curative maternal and newborn health care, with a positive health impact for the rural Zambian population.This was aimed at addressing the existing health care worker shortage which was a contributory factor to the high maternal and neonatal mortality rates in Zambia. The main objectives were: 1) Support the Ministry of Health (MoH) to develop and strengthen systems to train and enable 3,732 new ‘mid-level’ SBAs to provide quality preventive and curative maternal and newborn health care. It was expected that a minimum of 30% of students would be recruited from and subsequently deployed back to their rural communities.2) Strengthen Government of Zambia systems for supportive supervision and clinical mentorship of SBAs post-graduation in 14 districts across Northern, Muchinga and Luapula Provinces, and collect evidence to inform government policy decisions with regards to scaling up the system nationally.3) Collect evidence on retention strategies that could be successful in retaining health workers in rural areas across Zambia. The evidence collected would be shared with the Zambian Government to inform policy decisions around health worker retention strategies.

tag.narrative: 3.c - Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States.

3.c - Väsentligt stärka finansieringen av hälso- och sjukvården liksom insatserna för att rekrytera, utveckla, utbilda och behålla hälso- och sjukvårdspersonal i utvecklingsländerna, särskilt i de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
1.Increased the number of Skilled birth attendants:
CHAI assisted the Zambian MoH to improve rural enrollment and retention of health care workers by aiming to enroll 30% of students and deploying them back to serve in the rural areas after completion of training. This was based on the assumption that HCWs from rural origins were most likely to remain there. To enable government, achieve this goal, the first output of the grant was to train and enable 2,633 new ‘midlevel’ SBAs with 30% (789) eventually be deployed back to the rural areas by 2018. The grant exceeded this target by supporting 3,723 “mid-level” SBAs as primary beneficiaries and an additional 1,131 as secondary beneficiaries CHAI was responsible for the recruitment and training of 3,732 Mid-level SBAs broken as follows:• Clinical Officers General 748• Clinical Officers Anaesthesia 173• Nurses 2171• Direct Entry Midwives 473• Medical Licentiate 167 In addition 687 Specialists were trained as follows: Program of Study: Number of Students Trained BSc Human Nutrition 4 BSc Nursing 200 Advanced Diploma in Clinical Instructor 1 Advanced Diploma in Clinical Anesthesia 62 Advanced Diploma in Critical Care Nursing 32 Advanced Diploma in Pediatrics & Child Health Nursing 41 BSc Clinical Sciences 11 BSc in Nutrition & Dietetics 2 BSc Nursing & Midwifery 23 Certificate in Emergency Medical Care 5 Certificate in Midwifery 117 Certificate in Operating Theatre Nursing 32 MMed Anesthesia & IC 23 MMed General Surgery 36 MMed in Emergency Medicine 4 MMed in Pediatric Child Health 3 MMed Infectious diseases 5 MMed Internal Medicine 20 MMed Obstetrics & Gynecology 31 MMed Pediatrics & Child Health 18 MSc in Midwifery & Women's Health Programme 1 MSc in Nursing 11 MSc in Nursing & Midwifery 6 Total 687 Community Health Assistants In February of 2018, the scope of the grant was expanded to strengthen the Community Health Assistants (CHA) program. CHAs form an important link between the community and facilities providing preventive and curative services.This resulted in: 1. Increased number of qualified CHAs trained (support decentralized CHAI training)2. Strengthened systems for supportive supervision and clinical mentorship of CHAs3. Broadened evidence base for community health Provision of bridge funding for the CHA salaries- On June 1st, 2018, SIDA signed an amendment to the existing grant increasing the total cost of the grant from SEK 125,000, 000 to SEK 134,200,000. The increase was to allow for the provision of salary support for 316 CHAs from the Reproductive Maternal Newborn Child Adolescent Health & Nutrition (RMNCAHN)Program- Eastern, Southern, Muchinga and Luapula provinces for a period of six months as an interim measure, while MoH mobilized funds to absorb the CHAs onto its payroll. The MOH has since started absorbing the CHAs and intergrating them in the RMNCAHN program. 2.Infrastructural developments Investments in infrastructure were aimed at supporting the achievement of training targets under output-1 of the grant. Given the impact that SBAs have on service utilization a budgetary allocation for infrastructure was made to support the scaling up of capacity at targeted training institutions tentatively identified by MoH as Kasama School of Nursing, Mansa School of Nursing, Chainama College of Health Sciences, Solwezi School of Nursing and Lewanika Nursing and Midwifery School in 2014. The infrastructure plan was informed by findings of the National Training Operational Plan NTOP 2013-2016 which laid out a number of priority infrastructure needs for scale up. Chainama College of Health Sciences: Construction of double-storey integrated lecture theatre, skillslab & library including furnishings.
Construction of Medical Licentiate Hostel at Mansa General Hospital Kasama School of Nursing-Building 40 Bed student Hostel,150 seat classroom block and skills lab Lukupa – Kasama School of Nursing-Lukupa:Building admin block, library and skills lab
Skills lab. Mansa ML practicum site-Building 2 x 48 double-storey student hostels Solwezi ML practicum site-
All these facilities have since been handed over to the government. Equipment & transport
CHAI bought 18 mentorship vehicles and 28 Eranger vehicles for use in the program.These vehicles have since been handed over to the government for continued use in training and supervision of SBAs. In addition CHAI equipped the training institutions with ICT and other training equipment. 3. Strengthen Systems for Supportive Supervision and Clinical Mentorship of SBA & CHA Emergency Obstetric and New-born Care (EmONC) services are a set of interventions that address the direct causes of maternal and neonatal deaths. The specific interventions are referred to as signal functions. Health facilities, depending on the signal functions they regularly perform, are classified as providing either basic EmONC (BEmONC) or comprehensive EmONC (CEmONC). CHAI provided training & mentorship in EmONC and supported the development of the referral systems.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
